learning_objectives: Identify opaque, transparent, and translucent objects by their light-blocking properties
Explain how shadows form when light travels in straight lines and hits an opaque object
Describe how a pin-hole camera captures images using straight-line light travel
simulation_logic:
Step 1: Draw light source at angle specified by 'lightAngle' variable.
Step 2: Render selected object (shape+type) at fixed position.
Step 3a (Shadow Mode): Cast shadow behind object with opacity based on object type (opaque=100%, translucent=40%, transparent=0%).
Step 3b (Pin-Hole Mode): Show inverted image inside camera box when 'isPinHoleMode' is true.
Step 4: Update rendering continuously as sliders/buttons change
mobile_ui_plan:
Vertical layout:
1. Header: Title + objective (1 line)
2. Controls Section (scrollable horizontal row):
   - Light slider (width: 90%)
   - Object type buttons (3 equal columns)
   - Shape buttons (3 equal columns)
   - Camera toggle switch
3. Canvas View (full width, 60vh):
   - Light source icon
   - Object placeholder
   - Shadow/image display area
4. Instruction bar (fixed bottom): 2-line guidance text
misconceptions_to_address: Shadows are always completely black (show gray-scale gradients)
Transparent objects cannot cast any shadow (demonstrate faint shadows)
Pin-hole cameras work via light bending (emphasize straight-line travel)
text_instructions_for_students: Move the light slider to change shadow direction. Tap object buttons to test different materials. Switch to Camera Mode to see how pin-holes capture images. Observe how shadow darkness changes with object type!
safety_constraints: No external resources; all graphics rendered via HTML5 Canvas. No user data collection. Content strictly educational (CBSE Class 7 level).
